results.adx_keywords: Airlines and Airplanes;Customs, Etiquette and Manners;Flight Attendants;Content Type: Service;Travel and Vacations
results.title: ‘Never a Reason to Take Off Your Socks’: A Flight Attendant’s 12 Etiquette Rules
results.abstract: Air travel is going to be busy this summer. With some common sense and courtesy, could flying be … pleasant?

media.caption: There’s plenty to grumble about when it comes to flying these days. Still, a little kindness can go a long way toward a better summer season of air travel.

results.adx_keywords: Baseball;Major League Baseball
results.title: M.L.B.’s New Rules Have Baseball in Overdrive
results.abstract: Players are stealing more bases, more balls are falling for hits and games are nearly 30 minutes faster than they were last year. Like them or not, the rules are accomplishing their goals.

results.title: What Makes a Garden a Work of Art? Piet Oudolf Explains.
results.abstract: The noted designer of the High Line has wisdom to share with other gardeners: “I put plants on a stage and let them perform.”

media.caption: In his gardens, the Dutch landscape designer Piet Oudolf creates complex textural mosaics of muted colors. This one is at Hauser & Wirth Somerset, an international art gallery in South West England.

results.abstract: The death of Tim Keller is a chance to ponder his faith’s Trump-era path.

results.title: Make Swimming Your Summer Workout
results.abstract: With just 30 minutes and a few useful tricks, a trip to the pool can become serious exercise.

results.title: How to Light an Outdoor Space Without Infuriating Your Neighbors
results.abstract: Forget the floodlights. The key to effectively illuminating your yard or patio at night is subtlety.

media.caption: What makes summer nights even better? Artful outdoor lighting, like Nathan Orsman helped the interior designer Steven Gambrel create for Mr. Gambrel’s home in the Hamptons.

results.adx_keywords: Travel and Vacations;Hotels and Travel Lodgings;Writing and Writers;Maynard, Joyce;Guatemala;Lake Atitlan (Guatemala)
results.title: The Accidental Innkeeper: How an American Novelist Became a Hotelier in Guatemala
results.abstract: “These days, my role as an innkeeper occupies me almost as much as fiction,” writes Joyce Maynard, who, during the pandemic, hired locals in a Guatemalan village to turn her writing retreat into a guesthouse.

media.caption: Joyce Maynard’s guesthouse, Casa Paloma, on the banks of Lake Atitlán in Guatemala.

results.title: Study Offers New Twist in How the First Humans Evolved
results.abstract: A new genetic analysis of 290 people suggests that humans emerged at various times and places in Africa.

media.caption: Excavations at the Jebel Irhoud archaeological site in Morocco, where 300,000-year-old fossils that may be the oldest evidence of Homo sapiens were found in 2017.

results.title: Florida School Restricts Access to Amanda Gorman’s Inauguration Poem
results.abstract: A grade school in Miami-Dade County said “The Hill We Climb,” which Ms. Gorman read at President Biden’s inauguration in 2021, was “better suited” for older students after a parent complained about it.

results.title: The High-Risk Feat of Bringing ‘American Born Chinese’ to TV
results.abstract: For years, Gene Luen Yang was convinced a single character in his groundbreaking graphic novel would doom any attempt at an adaptation. What changed?

results.title: The Castle Where Future Queens Drop the Royal Act
results.abstract: At Atlantic College, a school in a 12th-century castle clinging to the windy Welsh coastline, teenage royals take classes on world peace.

media.caption: UWC Atlantic College, housed in a 12th-century castle on the unglamorous coastline of south Wales, is popular with Gen Z royalty.

results.adx_keywords: Social Media;Teenagers and Adolescence;Mental Health and Disorders;Parenting
results.title: How Parents Can Actually Help Teens Navigate Social Media
results.abstract: The U.S. surgeon general and the American Psychological Association have urged parents to monitor adolescents for “problematic” social media use. We asked experts for some realistic and effective ways to do this.

results.title: Heat Wave and Blackout Would Send Half of Phoenix to E.R., Study Says
results.abstract: New research warns that nearly 800,000 residents would need emergency medical care for heat stroke and other illnesses in an extended power failure. Other cities are also at risk.

results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;your-feed-health;Spine (Body Part);Paralysis;Implants;Brain;Artificial Intelligence;Nature (Journal);Lausanne (Switzerland)
results.title: A Paralyzed Man Can Walk Naturally Again With Brain and Spine Implants
results.abstract: In a new study, researchers describe a device that connects the intentions of a paralyzed patient to his physical movements.

media.caption: For more than a decade, Gert-Jan Oskam has been paralyzed from the waist down. On Wednesday, scientists described implants that provided a “digital bridge” between his brain and his spinal cord, bypassing injured sections and enabling him to walk.
